qas.question: How many of Andrew Johnson's veto's were over turned by Congress
What act did congress pass that gave the senate the right to approve the dismissal of a cabinet official?
After which war did Congress begin using power to counterbalance the President?
Who vetoed several bills passed by the Radical Democrats?
How many of Johnson's fifteen vetoes did Congress override?
How many of Congress' 29 vetoes did Johnson override?
Through which act did Jackson attempt to curb presidential power?

context: Some of Jackson's successors made no use of the veto power, while others used it intermittently. It was only after the <b2_0>Civil War<b2_0/> that presidents began to use the power to truly counterbalance Congress. <b3_0>Andrew Johnson<b3_0/>, a Democrat, vetoed several Reconstruction bills passed by the "Radical Republicans." Congress, however, managed to override <a0_0><b5_0>fifteen<b5_0/><a0_0/> of Johnson's <b4_0>twenty-nine<b4_0/> vetoes. Furthermore, it attempted to curb the power of the presidency by passing the <a1_0><b6_0>Tenure of Office Act<b6_0/><a1_0/>. The Act required Senate approval for the dismissal of senior Cabinet officials. When Johnson deliberately violated the Act, which he felt was unconstitutional (Supreme Court decisions later vindicated such a position), the House of Representatives impeached him; he was acquitted in the Senate by one vote.
